titleStmt.title: PEG TRANSFER WORKFLOW RECOGNITION CHALLENGE REPORT: DO MULTI-MODAL DATA IMPROVE RECOGNITION?

analytic.title: PEG TRANSFER WORKFLOW RECOGNITION CHALLENGE REPORT: DO MULTI-MODAL DATA IMPROVE RECOGNITION?

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

textClass.keywords: Surgical Process Model ? Workflow recognition ? Multi-modality ? OR of the future

div.head: arXiv:2202.05821v2 [cs.LG] 14 Apr 2022
div.p: A PREPRINT -APRIL 15, 2022 Background and Objective: Context-aware computer-assisted surgical systems require real-time automatic and accurate surgical workflow recognition. Since several years, video has been the most commonly used modality to develop surgical workflow recognition systems. With the democratization of robotic-assisted surgery and segmentation methods, new modalities are now accessible, such as kinematics. Some previous works used these new modalities as input of their models, but their added value has been rarely studied. This paper presents the design and results of the "PEg TRAnsfer Workflow recognition" (PETRAW) challenge whose objective was to develop surgical workflow recognition methods based on one or several modalities and to study their added value. Methods: The PETRAW challenge provided a data set of 150 peg transfer sequences performed on a virtual simulator. This data set included videos, kinematic data, semantic segmentation data, and workflow annotations that described the sequences at three granularity levels: phase, step, and activity. Five tasks were proposed to the participants: three were related to the recognition of all granularities using one of the available modalities, and the other two addressed the recognition with a combination of modalities. The mean application-dependent balanced accuracy (AD-Accuracy) value was used as evaluation metric to take unbalanced classes into account and because it is more clinically relevant than a frame-by-frame score. Results: Seven teams participated in at least one task and four of them in all tasks. The best results were obtained by combining video and the kinematic data (AD-Accuracy between 93% and 90% for the four teams who participated in all tasks). Conclusion: The improvement of video/kinematic-based surgical workflow recognition methods compared with uni-modality methods was significant for all teams. However, the longer testing execution time for video/kinematic-based than kinematic-based methods must be taken into account. Indeed, it could be asked whether it is relevant to spend 20 to 200 times more computing time to increase accuracy by 3% only. The PETRAW data set is publicly available at www.synapse.org/ PETRAW to encourage further research in surgical workflow recognition.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: To bring computer-assisted surgery systems inside the operating room, a complete and explicit understanding of surgical procedures is needed. A surgical process model (SPM), defined as a "simplified pattern of a surgical process that reflects a predefined subset of interest of the surgical process in a formal or semi-formal representation" [1], can bring this understanding. The SPM methodology consists of decomposing a surgical procedure into different levels of granularity: phases, steps, activities, surgemes, and dexemes [2,3]. A dexeme, the lowest granularity level, is a numerical representation of the motion. A surgeme represents a surgical motion with an explicit semantic meaning (e.g., pull). An activity describes a physical action (action verbs; e.g., cut) performed on a specific target (e.g., the pouch of Douglas) by a specific surgical instrument (e.g., a scalpel). A step is the succession of activities performed to achieve a surgical objective (e.g., resection of the pouch of Douglas). Finally, a phase corresponds to a main period of the intervention (e.g., resection) and is a succession of steps. The SPM methodology is used for learning and expertise assessment [4,5], robotic assistance [6], operating room optimization and management [7,8], decision-making support [9], and quality supervision [10].

The major limitation of SPM related state-of-the-art publications [3,4,5,7,9,10] is the need for SPMs manual acquisition by human observers. This is observer-dependent, time-consuming, and subject to errors [11]. Due to this limitation, the proposed solutions can not be directly used to bring context-awareness computer-assisted surgery applications inside the operating room. To overcome this limitation, automatic workflow recognition methods have been developed for each granularity level: phases [8,12,13] , steps [14,15] ,and activities [6,16]. Different modalities could be used for workflow recognition. For robotic-assisted surgeries and virtual reality training sessions, video and kinematic data are easily available. However, most state-of-the-art workflow recognition methods are based only on video [17,18], or kinematic data [3,19]. Only few studies used workflow recognition method based on both video and kinematic data. [20,21,22]. However, with the exception of the study by Long et.al. [21], these authors did not compare the results obtained using models based on more than one modality to those obtained using a single modality.. Semantic segmentation of the surgical scene also is very important for surgical understanding and is an active area of research. For example, in 5 editions of the EndoVis MICCAI Challenge (2015 to 2020), 6 of the 19 proposed sub-challenges were dedicated to this topic. However, to the best of our knowledge, semantic segmentation has been rarely used as a modality for surgical workflow recognition. Therefore, the "PEg TRAnsfer Workflow recognition by different modalities" (PETRAW) sub-challenge, which is part of EndoVis, provided a unique data set for automatic recognition of surgical workflows that contained video, kinematic, and segmentation data on 150 peg transfer training sequences. Participants were asked to develop model(s) to recognize phases, steps, and activities using one or several of the available modalities.

div.head: Methods: Challenge Design
div.p: This section describes the challenge design, organization, mission, data set, and assessment methods.

div.head: Challenge organization
div.p: The PETRAW challenge was a one-time event organized as part of EndoVis during the online 2021 international conference on Medical Image Computing and Computer-Assisted Intervention (MICCAI2021). Four people were involved in the organization: Arnaud Huaulm? and Pierre Jannin from Rennes University (France), Kanako Harada, and Mamoru Misthuishi from Tokyo University (Japan). Complete information on the challenge was available for the participants at the Synapse platform: www.synapse.org/PETRAW . Participation in the challenge was conditioned to the following rules: Participants had to submit a fully automatic method that could recognize phases, steps, and activities, on the same model, using one or several modalities. Only data provided by the organizers and publicly available data sets, including pre-trained networks, were authorized for the training. The publicly available data sets only covered data that were available to everyone when the PETRAW data set was released. The results of all participating teams were announced publicly during the challenge day. Challenge organizers and people from the organizing institutions could participate in the challenge but were not eligible for the competition. Participating teams were encouraged (but not required) to provide their code as open access.

For a valid submission, the participating teams had to provide the following elements: a write-up, a Docker image allowing the organizers to computed the results, and a pre-recorded talk to limit technical issues during the challenge day (online event). Multiple Docker images could be submitted, but only the last submission was officially used for the challenge results. No leader board or evaluation results were provided before the challenge end.

The challenge schedule was as follows. The videos, kinematic data and workflow annotations of the training data set were released on June 1, 2021; segmentation data were released on June 9, 2021. Submissions were accepted until September 12, 2021 (23:59 PST). Results were announced on October 1, 2021 during the online MICCAI2021. Some teams obtained unexpected results (i.e. workflow recognition rate inferior to 50%), which made the analysis of the results not relevant. Therefore, each team could provide a new submission before October 31, 2021. The teams who made a new submission are identified in Section 3.2. The challenge test data set and the organizers' evaluation scripts were released with this paper at www.synapse.org/PETRAW

div.head: Challenge mission
div.p: The PETRAW challenge objective was to study the contribution to automatic workflow recognition of each modality alone or in combination with other modalities. To achieve this goal, participants were asked to recognize, using one model, all levels of granularity of the surgical workflow (i.e. phases, steps, and action verbs) in five different tasks (based on the use of one or more of available modalities). Three tasks concerned the development of single modality-based models (i.e. video-based, kinematic-based, or semantic segmentation-based models). These models were then used as baseline for comparison with the other two tasks that concerned the development of multi-modality-based models (i.e. video + kinematic based model or video + kinematic + semantic segmentation-based model). Not all multi-modality configurations were studied to limit the task number. For models based on semantic segmentation data, and to reflect the fact that clinically this modality is only available through computation, participants were asked to use the output of a segmentation method as input for PETRAW.

div.head: Challenge data set
div.p: The challenge data set was composed of 150 sequences of peg transfer training sessions. The objective of the peg transfer session is to transfer six blocks from the left to the right and back. Each block must be extracted from a peg with a grasper (driven by on hand), transferred to the other grasper (driven by the other hand), and inserted in a peg on the other side of the board. All sequences were acquired by a non-medical expert at the LTSI Laboratory, Rennes University, France. The data set was divided into training data set (n=90 sequences) and test data set (n=60 sequences). Each sequence included kinematic and video data, semantic segmentation of each frame, and workflow annotation. Only the training data set was provided to participants.

div.head: Data acquisition
div.p: The challenge data were acquired on a virtual reality simulator (figure 1) developed at the Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Tokyo, Japan [23] and composed of a core laptop (i7-700HQ, 16Go RAM, GTX 1070), a 3D rendering setup (3D screen: 24 inches, 144Hz; and 3D glasses), and two haptic user interfaces (3D system Touch TM ). Data acquisition was divided into sessions of five sequences. A minimum of 5 hours of resting time was observed between sessions to limit participant's fatigue. The COVID-19 crisis did not allow us to recruit several participants to have a comparable number of sequences per subjects. To limit the effect of immediate learning or fatigue in a single session, three sequence of each session were randomly chosen for training and the other two for testing.

The kinematic and scene information were synchronously acquired at 30 Hz during the task simulation. Scene information included the data used to generate the 2D video and the semantic segmentation data after the session at a resolution of 1920x1080 pixels.

Kinematic data represented the position, rotation quaternion, forceps aperture angle, Linear velocity (obtained from simulation, not derived from position), and Angular velocity (obtained from simulation, not derived from orientation) of the left and right instruments (i.e., graspers). Position and linear velocity were in centimeters; angle, and angular velocity in degrees.

Semantic segmentation data included six classes (figure 2): background (black, hexadecimal code :#000000), base (white, #FFFFFF), left instrument (red, #FF0000), right instrument (green, #00FF00), pegs (blue, #0000FF), and blocks (magenta, #FF00FF). The workflow annotations were automatically computed using the scene information and the ASURA method [11].Two phases, twelve steps, six action verbs, two targets, and one surgical instrument were identified to described the workflow ( Table 1). Each phase corresponded to one transferring direction. Each step (six per phase) corresponded to the transfer of one block in one direction (e.g."Block1 L2R" describes the transfer of the first block from the left to the right). For the activities, two targets were differentiated: "block" and "other block". The "block" corresponds to the one that is currently transferred. "Other block" is an additional target used to differentiate when the user accidentally interacts with another block. One limitation of the method presented by [11] was the inability to differentiate correctly the action verbs "catch" and "touch". Since then, the information provided by the VR simulator was enhanced to allow making this difference. Moreover, each workflow annotation was manually reviewed to ensure the annotation quality.

div.head: Data pre-processing
div.p: A workflow annotation is the description of a task where each element is characterized by its beginning and its end, expressed in milliseconds. This was modified to provide a discrete sequence synchronized at 30Hz with the kinematic, video, and segmentation data. Due to their lack of variability, the two targets and the tool were not included in the workflow description. Furthermore, when no phase, step, or activity occurred, the term "idle" was used. For each timestamp, the following information was provided: timestamp_number, phase_value, step_value, verb_Left_Hand, verb_Right_Hand.

div.head: Ground truth uncertainties
div.p: The segmentation masks were the main source of ground truth uncertainty. Due to the transformation of 3D meshes in 2D images, some pixels were attributed to the wrong class, especially at boundaries between the right instrument/peg, left instrument/peg, left instrument/block, and left/right instruments. ( figure 3). This error was estimated to concern less than 0.5% of pixels.

Workflow annotations were another source of uncertainty. Although the ASURA method is consistent (i.e. same result provided for two identical situations) and a manual check was performed to limit uncertainties, some components could not be well recognized. Two uncertainties were identified. First, in sequence 130 of the training data-set, the block in step "Block 1 R2L" was inserted in a non-standard way. Specifically, the block was released by the operator and while falling becam inserted in the peg. Therefore, the insert action was absent. The other uncertainty concerned sequence 79 off the test data-set. Here, the operator caught a block before the previous one was fully inserted, leading to an overlap shorter than 0.5 seconds between the steps "Block 5 R2L" and "Block 6 R2L". It was chosen to maintain the true beginning of the second step.

div.head: Data sets characteristics
div.p: The training and test data sets presented similar characteristics. The mean and standard deviation duration was 140.2 ? 18.9 seconds for the training data set and 141.7 ? 18.0 seconds for the test data set. Figure 4 presents the distribution of each vocabulary component for each granularity level in the training data set (figures 4a, 4c, 4e, 4g) and the test data set (figures 4b, 4d, 4f, 4h). Even for underrepresented components, the distribution was very similar in both data sets. For instance, the verb touch (left hand) represented 0.59% and 0.60% of the samples in training and test data sets, respectively, and touch (right hand) represented 0.62% and 0.48%, respectively.

Another important characteristic of the data sets was the high class unbalance of at least one vocabulary term for each granularity. For phases and steps, the term "idle" represented less than 4% of all data, whereas the other terms represent more than 47% (L2R and R2L) and 7.5% (other steps), respectively (figures 4a-4d). This unbalance was more pronounced for verbs, where the least represented verb ("touch") represented approximately 0.6% of the dataset, whereas the verb "idle" corresponded to more than 53%. The detailed distribution values for each granularity in both data sets are in supplementary material.

div.head: Metrics
div.p: To assess the participants' workflow recognition models and to take into account the high class unbalance, the balanced version of accuracy, precision, recall, and F1 were used. In practice, a clinical application does not need to be precise at the frame resolution. Dergachyova et al. [24], proposed a re-estimation of the classic scores, called application-dependent scores, to take into account an acceptable delay d. When a predicted transition occurs inside a transition window (2d) centered on the ground truth transition, all frames between the two transitions are considered correct if it is the same transition type ( e.g. transition for verb "catch" or verb "extract"). Therefore, the balanced application-dependent accuracy (AD-Accuracy) was used and the acceptable delay was fixed at 250 ms.

To assess the participants' segmentation models, the mean Intersection-Over-Union (IoU) over all classes was used, also known as the Mean Jaccard Index over all classes. The IoU is the area of overlap between the predicted segmentation (P red) and the ground truth (GT ), divided by the area of union between the P red and the GT . In our cases, there was
div.formula: = 1 6 class T P class T P class + F P class + F N class ,
div.p: where TP is the number of True Positives, FP the number of False Positives, and FN the number of False Negatives for each class.

div.head: Ranking method
div.p: Only the workflow recognition models were ranked. The metric computed for the segmentation models was used for information purposes.

A mean metric-based aggregation method using the AD-Accuracy values was used for the ranking. For each participant, the metric values were aggregated over all test sequences to obtain a final score for the ranking. A metric-based aggregation was used according to the conclusion by [25], who showed that this type of aggregation is one of the most robust.
As all tasks consisted of recognizing the phase, step, left and right verbs, the ranking score for the algorithm a i was computed as follows:
div.formula: s(a i ) = s phase (a i ) + s step (a i ) + s verb_lef t (a i ) + s verb_right (a i ) 4(2)
div.p: with,
div.formula: s phase (a i ) = T t=0 phase_balance_accuracy_case_t T(3)
div.p: Equation 3 was used for s step , s verb_left and s verb_right .

In the case of missing results, results were considered as good as the total random recognition. For example, for a 3-class problem, the missing result would be set at 1/3, and for a 12-class problem, it would be set at 1/12. In practice, this case was not encountered.

The ranking stability was assessed by testing different ranking methods: meanThenRank, medianThenRank, rank-ThenMean, rankThenMedian, and testBased. MeanThenRank was chosen for the ranking. MedianThenRank differs from the previous method because it used the median instead of the mean in equation 3. For rankThenMean and rankThenMedian, first, the results of each sequence were ranked among participants, then the final results were the mean or median of all ranks. The testBased method is based on bootstrapping. If the ranking was not stable according to the chosen methods, a tie between teams was pronounced.
The ranking computation and analysis were performed with the ChallengeR package provided by [26].

div.head: Online recognition compatibility
div.p: To be online compatible, the proposed methods must satisfy two conditions:to spend less time between two predictions than the duration between the two samples and to be causal(i.e., they must not use future samples to predict the current one).

The computation time was not studied, because it could not be assessed for all teams. Indeed, teams provided a unique Docker image for all tasks, and some teams did not write the output file on the flow.

To check the causality of the proposed method, the online availability of the frames was mimicked. One additional sequence of 10 seconds, which corresponds to the transfer of the first block from the left to the right, was recorded. Then, this sequence was split into 300 sequences, each one having the information of the next frame in addition to all the information of the previous sequence. Thus, the first sequence only contained the information of the first frame, the second one contained the information of the two first frames, etc. All models were run to predict the workflows, and then the sequence provided by the last prediction of the split sequences was compared to the prediction of the complete sequence. A model was considered causal only if the results were the same.

For computation time and environmental responsibility reasons, this test was not performed on a whole sequence or the whole test data set. Indeed, this would have corresponded to test more than 4 250 split sequences per test sequence or more than 255 000 split sequences for the whole test data set.
3 Results: Reporting of the Challenge Outcomes

div.head: Challenge submission
div.p: On September 12, 2021, 29 participants had registered for the PETRAW challenge: 17 were members of one of the six competing teams. The organizers also submitted results as a non-competing team to provide a baseline. As explained in Section 2.1, some teams obtained unexpected results. Three teams resubmitted results for at least one task.

div.head: Information on the participating teams and their methods
div.p: This section describes each team, the methods they used, and which tasks they participated in. Competing teams are presented in alphabetical order and not in function of their ranking.

div.head: Hutom
div.p: The Hutom team (Bogyu Park, Seungbum Hong, and Minkook Choi from VisionAI hutom) participated in all proposed tasks. They resubmitted a Docker image for all tasks except the kinematic-based recognition task.

Before training, they did a preprocessing step. To preserve temporal information, they split data into clips of 8 frames. They normalized kinematic data by standardizing the raw input without data augmentation. They resized video data at 256 x 256 pixels, followed by random cropping (224 x 224 pixels) and normalization. They did cropping to preserve the spatial information off each frame in one clip. They resized segmentation data at 512 x 512 pixels.

They used a similar baseline architecture for tasks based on the same modality. They computed segmentation data from the video recording using a DeepLabV3+ architecture [27]. They used a 3D ResNet network [28] for workflow recognition based on the video modality. For the segmentation modality, they used a SlowFast50 network [29] for segmentation-based recognition and a 3D ResNet network for video/kinematic/segmentation based workflow recognition. They inputted kinematic data on abi-directional long short term memory (Bi-LSTM) network [30]. For multi-modality recognition tasks, they used a convolutional feature fusion layer to efficiently perform the fusion of the feature output of each modality. They obtained embedding features with individual modality inputs from each model trained accordingly. Then, they compared the embedding features of each modality with those of other modalities to learn the different representations off each modality. They used the stop gradient-based SimSiam method [31] to compare representations between embedding features. Concomitantly, they stacked embedding features by modality into one block as a chunk and fused them into one embedding through convolution operation. The approach assumed that feature elements for each modality in the same column have similar temporal information in similar positions. For all networks, they used the Adam optimizer and an initial learning rate of 1e -3 , with a combination of Equalization loss v2 [32] and Normsoftmax Loss [33] as long-tail recognition for solving data imbalance.

div.head: JHU-CIRL
div.p: The JHU-CIRL team (Michael Peven and Gregory D. Hager; Johns Hopkins University) participated in the kinematicbased workflow recognition task.

They performed an under-sampling of the kinematic data to reduce time dimension size in order to prevent vanishing gradient issues during training. For the test, they used the same under-sampling. The JHU-CIRL team did not perform other preprocessing steps because they considered that besides positional data, the addition of velocity data was sufficient for the recognition.

They used an unidirectional LSTM network [34] to recognize the four workflow components. They trained the model using traditional cross-entropy loss and the Adam optimizer. They paid special attention to the selection of the following hyperparameters: sampling rate, learning rate, LSTM hidden dimension size, and the number of layers in the LSTM. They run a 5-fold cross-validation to obtain results from each of these hyperparameters. Then, they selected the best set of hyperparameters for the final training: 15Hz sampling rate, 1e -3 learning rate, 256 LSTM Hidden dimension, and 2 LSTM layers. 9

div.head: MedAIR
div.p: The MedAIR team (Yunshuang Li, Yonghao Long, and Qi Dou, Zhejiang University and the Chinese University of Hong Kong) participated in three tasks: video-based, kinematic-based, and video/kinematic-based workflow recognition. They resubmitted a Docker image for the video-based workflow recognition task.

The MedAIR team resized videos at 224 x 224 pixels and then augmented the data using a random horizontal flip and a random rotation of 5?. For kinematic data, they used a linear layer to obtain 2048 dimensions from the 28 dimensions to enrich the information.

For single modality-based workflow recognition (video-based and kinematic-based tasks), the MedAIR team uses a Trans-SVNet model [35]. First, they trained two different convolutional neural networks (CNN) to extract spatial features, one for steps and another for left and right verbs. Then, they trained three multi-stage temporal convolutional networks (TCN) to obtain temporal features for steps and verbs. Finally, they used three transformer layers to combine spatial and temporal features to obtain the final output for the three labels. Phases were not directly predicted by the networks, but identified based on the predicted step. They used a stochastic gradient descent (SGD) optimizer with a cross-entropy loss and a learning rate of 5e -4 .

For multi-modality-based workflow recognition (video/kinematic-based task), they used a multi-modal relational graph network (MRG-Net) [21]. Like for single modality-based workflow recognition, they used two CNNs to extract features from each frame in the video for steps and verbs. Then, they obtained the step labels using the original MRG-Net structure, which was the result of the fully connected layer with the output of three nodes in the graph. For the verb labels, the MedAIR team used the output of k l t and k r t with fully connected layers, respectively, to obtain the final label prediction for left verb and right verb labels. They identified phases based on the predicted step. They used an Adam optimizer with cross-entropy loss and learning rate of 1e -4 .

div.head: MMLAB
div.p: The MMLAB team was composed of Satyadwyoom Kumar, Lalithkumar Seenivasan, Hongliang Ren from the Netaji Subhas University of Technology, National University of Singapore, and the Chinese University of Hong Kong. They participated in the video/kinematic-based recognition task.

MMLAB team proposed a multi-task learning model to perform the recognition. First, each video frame was resized at 224 x 224 pixels. A ResNet 50 [36] pre-trained on ImageNet was used to extract visual features for each video frame. These features were passed with the frame-specific kinematic data through four label-specific networks (one by component). Each label-specific network was composed of two LSTMs [37], one by modality, to capture the temporal features. The sequential length was set to 5, allowing the model to infer based on the current and past 4 temporal information. The resultant temporal features were then passed through a single linear layer for recognition. Each label-specific network was trained independently with cross-entropy loss, Adam optimizer, and a learning rate of 1e -3 for phase and step recognition, and 1e -2 for hand verbs.

div.head: NCC NEXT
div.p: The NCC NEXT team (Hiroki Matsuzaki, Yuto Ishikawa, Kazuyuki Hayashi, Yuriko Harai, and Nobuyoshi Takeshita, National Cancer Center Japan East Hospital) participated in all proposed tasks. They resubmitted a Docker image for all tasks except the kinematic-based recognition task.

They resized the initial video frames at a resolution of 512 x 256 pixels for video-based workflow recognition and of 480 x 270 pixels for segmentation-based workflow recognition. This was followed by normalization. They did not perform any preprocessing of kinematic data.

For video-based workflow recognition they used Xception networks [38] pre-trained on ImageNet, one per component. They used the Radam optimizer [39] with different learning rates with a batch size of 4, 1e -3 for phases and steps, and 1e -4 with a cosine decay scheduler for hand verbs. They also used cross-entropy loss.

For kinematic-based workflow recognition, the NCC NEXT used the light gradient boosting machine (LightGBM) framework [40]. Like for the previous task, they did the training and tuning of hyperparameters (i.e. learning rate, minimum data in leaf, number of iterations, and number of leaves) separately for each component ( Table 2: Hyperparameters for the kinematic based model developed by the NCC NEXT team The segmentation was performed by a Deeplabv3+ architecture [27] with an Xception backbone pre-trained on the Pascal visual object classes (PascalVOC) dataset [41]. With the predicted segmentation, they trained a multi-output classification model, based on the EfficientNetB7 architecture [42], with Radam optimizer, cross-entropy loss function, a learning rate of 0.0001 with a cosine decay scheduler, and a batch size of 16.

For the multi-modality workflow recognition tasks, the NCC NEXT team selected the method used in the three previous tasks that displayed the highest accuracy for each component. Specifically, for video/kinematic-based workflow recognition task, they used the video-based architecture for phase and step recognition and the kinematic-based architecture for hand verb recognition. For the video/kinematic/segmentation-base model, they used the video-based architecture for phase recognition, the segmentation-based architecture for step recognition, and the kinematic-based architecture for hand verb recognition.

div.head: SK
div.p: The SK team (Satoshi Kondo, Muroran Institute of Technology) participated in all proposed tasks.

For preprocessing, the SK team resized images to 640 x 353 pixels and then used shift (maximum shift size of 10% of the image size), scaling (0.9 to 1.1 times), rotation (-5 to 5 degrees), color jitter (-0.9 to 1.1 times for brightness, contrast, saturation, and hue), and Gaussian blur (maximum sigma value = 1.0) for image augmentation. Finally, the images were normalized and kinematic data were normalized in each dimension.

For the video-based workflow recognition task, the SK team used a 18-layer ResNet network [36], pre-trained on ImageNet. The SK team omitted the final fully-connected layer of ResNet and fed a 512-dimensional feature vector into three fully-connected layers to obtain steps and hand verbs. Each fully-connected layer included two ReLU and Dropout layers after the first layers. The team used an Adam optimizer, with learning rate changes with cosine annealing with an initial value of 7.2e -4 , and a batch size of 96. The team optimized the initial learning rates for each task with the Optuna library [43]. The team chose cross-entropy loss as loss function, with weights for each class depending on the class frequency for hand verbs. Phases were not directly predicted from the image, but identified based on the predicted step.

The SK team used an LSTM [37] with 28 hidden layers for the kinematic-based workflow recognition task. The LSTM output was fed into three fully connected layers as done for the previous task. The same optimizer and loss function were used. The initial learning rate was 1.5e -3 with a batch size of 6 and the number of data in a sequence was 30.

Image segmentation was done using the U-Net architecture [44] with ResNet18 as encoder with the summation of cross-entropy loss and dice loss. The SK team exploited the same model used for the video-based workflow recognition task also for the segmentation-based task. Both models were trained separately with an Adam optimizer and an initial learning rate of 2.4e -5 with a batch size of 32 for segmentation, and a learning rate of 1e -4 with a batch size of 6 for recognition.

For the video/kinematic-based task and video/kinematic/segmentation-based task, the SK team assembled the dedicated modality networks previously trained to make the recognition. As the SK team used the network parameters trained for the previous task, they did not train any network for these tasks.

div.head: MediCIS: non-competing team
div.p: The MediCIS team was a non-competing team due to the presence of challenge organizers (Quang-Minh Nguyen and Arnaud Huaulm?, Rennes University). The team participated in all proposed tasks.
For the preprocessing step, they resized frames at 256 x 512 pixels. Additionally, to train the segmentation model, they down-sampled data to 6 Hz. They z-normalized the kinematic data.

For the video-based workflow recognition task, the MediCIS team used a hierarchical RestNet50 network [36] pretrained on ImageNet to extract spatial features. Then, they used a Multi-Stage Temporal Convolutional Network called MS-TCN++ [45], with two stages, trained from scratch.
For the kinematic-based workflow recognition task, they directly used data as features for a two-stage MS-TCN++.

They selected as segmentation model a U-Net [46] network trained from scratch with the ADAM optimizer, crossentropy loss, learning rate of 1e -4 , and batch size of 10. Like for the video-based task, workflow recognition was done by hierarchical ResNet50 followed by a two-stage MS-TCN++.

For the video/kinematic-based and video/kinematic/segmentation-based tasks, the MediCIs team extracted singlemodality spatial features using a hierarchical ResNet50 network for video and segmentation data, followed by concatenation. Then, they trained a two-stage MS-TCN++.

They trained all workflow recognition models with the Adam optimizer, cross-entropy loss, learning rate of 1e -4 , and batch size of 2. For the hierarchical ResNet50 network, they emphasized the training for granularities that are harder to recognize using the following weights in the loss: 1 for phases, 2 for steps, and 5 for each hand's verbs. They set the number of dilated convolutional layers in MS-TCN++ to 10, except for the first layer where it was 11. The number of feature maps for each layer was 64.

div.head: Workflow recognition results
div.p: All results were computed on the organizers' hardware via the provided Docker images. This section only presents the results used for the ranking (balanced AD-Accuracy). Other results, such as application-dependent scores for each sequence and task, for each participating team, are available as supplementary material and at www.synapse.org/ PETRAW.

div.head: Task 1: video-based workflow recognition
div.p: Task 1 consisted in recognizing phases, steps, and hand verbs using video data only. Table 3 Causal X Table 3: Algorithms used for task 1. Team who resubmitted models are highlighted with an asterisk.

Comparison of the mean AD accuracy values for each test sequence (all models) ( Figure 5) showed only a slight performance decrease (from 95.1% to 82.2%), but for sequences 79 and 54 that displayed the lowest performance (77.7% and 72.9%, respectively). Moreover, for all the test sequences, one model displayed lower AD-Accuracy values than the other models. Comparison of the mean AD-Accuracy value for each model ( Figure 6 showed that team SK and team Hutom, obtained the highest values (>90%), followed by team MediCIS and team NCC NEXT (>87%). MedAIR obtained the lowest results (?84%). Team ranking was not influenced by the chosen method (Figure 7), except for the ranking of the SK and Hutom teams using the rankThenMedian and testBased methods.

div.head: Task 2: Kinematic-based workflow recognition
div.p: Task 2 consisted in recognizing phases, steps, and hand verbs using kinematic data only. Causal X X X Table 4: Summary of the models used for task 2

Like for task 1, the performances per sequence slightly decreased ( Figure 8). The highest AD-Accuracy values were superior to 90% for all teams. Three sequences (including sequences 79 and 54) had mean AD-Accuracy values inferior to 80%. Unlike task 1, the majority of sequences did not have outliers. Results were very similar among teams ( Figure 9). Four had a mean AD-Accuracy value between 89.7% and 90.7%, and the other two displayed mean AD-accuracy values of 86.4% and 84.3%, respectively. Ranking was not stable for team SK and team MediCIS (figure 10). As MediCIS was a non-competing team, SK was ranked third for this task.

div.head: Task 3: Segmentation-based workflow recognition
div.p: Task 3 consisted of recognizing phases, steps, and hand verbs using semantic segmentation data only. First, the results of the segmentation models provided by the participants will be described, and then the workflow recognition models. Table 5 summarizes the methods used by the four participating teams to perform semantic segmentation.

div.head: Segmentation models
div.formula: Team Hutom * NCC Next * SK MediCIS Preprocessing X X X X Augmentation X X Model DeepLabV3+ DeepLabV3+ U-Net U-Net Optimizer Adam Radam Adam Adam

div.head: Loss Equalization v2 & Normsoftmax cross-entropy cross-entropy cross-entropy
div.p: Learning Rate 1e -3 1e -4 2.4e -5 1e -4 Table 5: Segmentation models used for task 3. Team who resubmitted models are highlighted with an asterisk.

Comparison of the IoU values for each class of each sequence independently and for all classes (Macro) ( Table 6) showed that, the IoU varied between 94.0% and 91.1% for Macro. Pegs were the least recognized structure (IoU between 83.9% and 82.3%). Specific sequences with lower performance were not identified. (Table 7) showed similar Macro results for the NCC Next, SK and MediCIS teams ( 96.9%, 96.4%, and 94.0%, respectively).

div.head: Comparison of the mean IoU values of each team for all classes (Macro) and for each class independently
div.p: The Hutom team's Macro IoU was the lowest (85.0%), mainly due to the a IoU for pegs (63.3%). Figure 11 presents the ground truth and the segmentation results of each team for one frame. Figure 11: Ground truth (a) and segmentation results for each team (b to e) for one frame. Table 8 summarizes the methods used by the four participating teams to perform the workflow recognition.

div.head: Workflow models
div.p: Comparison of the mean AD-Accuracy values for each test sequence ( Figure 12) showed that performance decrease from 87.5% to 76.6%. The same two sequences (79 and 54) displayed very low results (67.4% and 65.5%, respectively). Moreover, for all test cases, one model had results lower than 70%. Table 8: Summary of the models used for task 3 (segmentation-based workflow recognition). Team who resubmitted models are highlighted with an asterisk. Comparison of the mean AD-Accuracy value for each model indicated that three teams obtained results between 88.5% and 87.2%, whereas the Hutom team had a mean AD-Accuracy value of 60.3% ( Figure 13). Figure 13: Mean recognition AD-Accuracy for each model for task 3. Each dot represents the AD-Accuracy for one sequence.

A PREPRINT -APRIL 15,2022 The method choice did not influence the team ranking, except for the second (NCC NEXT) and the third (MediCIS) rank ( Figure 14). Figure 14: Task 3 recognition ranking stability using the indicated ranking methods.

div.head: Task 4: video/kinematic-based workflow recognition
div.p: Task 4 consisted of recognizing phases, steps, and hand verbs using video and kinematic data. Table 9 summarizes the method used by the six participating teams.

AD-Accuracy values for each sequence were similar to those of the previous tasks (figure 15). Indeed, performance slightly decreased from 95.1% to 83.1% for most sequences, and was again low for sequences 79 and 54 (81.2% and 76.5%). For this task, the number of outliers was limited. The NCC NEXT team obtained the best results ( Figure 16), with an mean AD-Accuracy of 93.1%, followed by SK, Hutom, and MediCIS teams with results between 91.6% and 90.2%. For the last two teams, AD-Accuracy was superior to 84.5%.

div.head: Task 5: video/kinematic/segmentation-based workflow recognition
div.p: In task 5, teams recognized phases, steps, and hand verbs using video, kinematic and segmentation data. Table 10 summarizes the recognition methods used by the four participating teams. The models to create the segmentation were the same as those described in Table 5.

div.head: Team
div.p: Hutom Causal Table 10: Models used for task 5. Teams who resubmitted models are highlighted with an asterisk.
div.formula: * NCC NEXT * SK MediCIS Preprocessing X X X X Augmentation X X Model 3D ResNet & Bi-LSTM Xception, EfficientNetB7 & LightGBM ResNet18 & LSTM ResNet50 & MS-
div.p: As for the previous tasks, the mean AD-Accuracy values per sequence ( Figure 18) highlighted a slight decrease of performance (from 97.2% to 85.9%). Sequences 79 and 54 again displayed the lowest performances (80.8% and 78.0%, respectively). The teams' mean AD-Accuracy values ranged between 93.1% and 89.8% ( Figure 19). The SK and Hutom teams displayed very similar results with (91.4% and 91.3%, respectively). However, the chosen ranking method did not influence the final rank ( Figure 20). Table 11 summarizes the results of each team for the five tasks. All best methods displayed mean AD-Accuracy superior to 90%, except for task 3. Table 11: Mean AD-Accuracy of each team for the five tasks. The best results are highlighted in bold for each task. Resubmitted models are highlighted with an asterisk.

div.head: Discussion
div.p: An accurate surgical workflow recognition method is mandatory to develop automatic context-aware computer-assisted surgical systems. The proposed methods obtained good results but were not perfect, although the PETRAW dataset present several limitations. Specifically, the peg transfer task is easier than a real surgical intervention because the environment is simpler, the objects are clearly identified, the field of view is always the same, and the lighting is constant. Furthermore, all sequences were performed by the same operator. Therefore the PETRAW dataset variability was limited.

By analyzing the recognition of the workflow of individual sequence , we observed, for all tasks, a slight decrease in performance, but for two sequences (54 and 79) that displayed very low AD-Accuracy compared with all the other sequences, whatever the modality. We analyzed these two sequences in details to understand this poor performance. In sequence 54, the block was dropped twice during the transfer between hands, forcing the operator to catch again the block. Moreover, one block got stuck on the peg, forcing the operator to touch the block. Sequence 79, is one the of sequences identified as containing uncertainty (see Section 2.3.3); however, the overlapping steps (by 0.5 seconds) did not explain the low performance because their overlapping was partially compensated by the delay of 0.25 seconds used to compute the AD-Accuracy. In addition, a block got stuck on a peg in this sequence, and the order in which the blocks were caught, did not correspond to the one used in most sequences. These deviations from the most common workflow might explain the low performances.

For task 1 (video-based recognition), ResNet-based models gave the best results, and the simplest model was ranked first. For task 2 (kinematic-based recognition), LSTM-based methods presented the lowest results. For task 3, the two segmentation models used (DeepLabV3 and U-Net), displayed similar IoU values and the differences were probably due to differences in the training characteristics. For workflow recognition, the EfficientNetB7 and ResNet models obtained similar results. For tasks 4 and 5, the NCC NEXT team's strategy (i.e., using for each workflow component the modality that gave the best results in the single-modality tasks) provided the best result.

For the segmentation-based recognition task (task 3), the segmentation quality seems to influence workflow recognition, up to a certain threshold. Indeed, the workflow recognition performances of the three teams with Macro IoU values superior to 94.0% were similar ( AD-Accuracy between 88.5% and 87.2%), but the ranking was inverted for the two first teams. Conversely, the workflow recognition performance of with a Macro IoU value of 85% dropped drastically (60.3%). Additional work is required to confirm that the segmentation quality influences the workflow recognition, up to a certain threshold, because in this challenge, teams used different combinations of segmentation and workflow recognition models.

For tasks 1 to 4, at least one team submitted a causal model. Causal models generally have lower performance than acausal models. Surprisingly, except for task 4, the causal models displayed performances close to that of the best model. For example, for task 2, the AD-Accuracy of the best model was 90.7%, compared with 90.3% and 89.7% of the causal models by NCC NEXT and by SK, respectively. Obviously, it is not possible to conclude that causal models give similar results as acausal models: i) because during the challenge we did not have the two versions of a similar model, ii) because of data simplicity. Nevertheless, the result of the causal models are promising for developing applications, such as the implementation of an automatic reports after training sessions on a virtual simulator.

Among the seven participating teams, four teams (Hutom, NCC Next, SK, and MediCIS) participated in multi-modality tasks (tasks 4 and 5) with a combination of the same or similar models used for the single-modality tasks. This allowed assessing the impact of each modality and their combinations on automatic workflow recognition. For all cases, the recognition was improved when using several modalities; however, the addition of the segmentation modality decreased the performance. Comparison of the results obtained for single modality and multi-modality tasks with the Wilcoxon test (Table 12) confirmed the significant performance improvement when using multi-modality models, except between task 2 and task 5 for the MediCIS team. The decreased performance upon addition of the segmentation modality to the video/kinematic-based models was only significant for the MediCIS team. Therefore, the combination of video and kinematic data seems to give better results compared with other modality combinations.

div.head: Team
div.p: Hutom Table 12: Significant performance modification between single-modality and multi-modality tasks. T1 <> T4: comparison of task 1 and task 4; X: significant performance variation (p-value <0.05.
div.formula: NCC NEXT SK MediCIS T1 <> T4 X X X X T2 <> T4 X X X X T1 <> T5 X X X X T2 <> T5 X X X T3 <> T5 X X X X T4 <> T5 X
div.p: Performances are not the only important factor when developing automatic recognition models. Indeed, the environmental aspect also must be taken into account [47]. To answer this question, we examined the execution time to compute the results of the sixty test sequences (Table 13). These durations were an interpolation assuming that the results of each task was computed independently, and not the real computation time. For example, the Hutom team used the results of tasks 1 to 3 to provide the results of tasks 4 and 5. For NCC Next team, the duration could not be determined because the results were locally written at the end of the Docker image execution. Execution time was very different among 24 teams, and the shortest (with the exception of task 2) times were for the SK team. The shortest execution times were obtained for task 2 (3 min for SK and less than 1 minute for the Hutom and MediCIS teams). Although the performance results of task 4 were better, it was more time-consuming than task 2 (53, 57, and 203 minutes for SK, Hutom, and MediCIS, respectively). One may ask whether it makes sense to spend 20 to 200 times more computing time for less than 3% improvement. The training time should also be taken into account, because it is much more time-consuming [48,49]. However, we did not have access to this information. Data storage also should be considered. Videos can require a lot of storage space, especially for long surgical intervention. Conversely, kinematic data are less voluminous. The results for each team by sequence and task are presented on the following pages. Eight balanced scores were computed, the frame-by-frame and application-dependent version of the accuracy, precision, recall, and F1. To limit the

CBD: Could not Be Determined Future works should focus on compensating the limitations of the current dataset by including peg transfer sequences performed by several operators in different systems. Moreover, tests on more realistic data are necessary to validate the finding that kinematic data display the best performance in recognition rate and are the most environmentally responsible.[49] Emma Strubell, Ananya Ganesh, and Andrew Mccallum.
